Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assembling the Echinoderm Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Echinoderms include familiar animals such as starfishes, sea urchins, and a wide array of extinct forms stretching back to the Cambrian Period, circa 500 million years ago. Echinoderms share a common ancestor with backboned animals and thus provide a crucial link to understanding a huge portion of the entire tree of life as well as the history of our species. This project, the Echinoderm Tree of Life Project, will resolve the phylogenetic placement of Echinoderms within the tree of life and clarify important unresolved relationships among major echinoderm lineages using data from genetic sequencing and anatomy.

Echinoderms are fascinating, and their unique features, such as mutable ligaments and novel means of detecting light, have biomedical engineering applications. Because research on such marine animals and their adaptations is naturally attractive to young people, excellent students are expected to be recruited and the importance of science will be communicated to a broad audience. Long-term impacts, embodied by scientific publications, textbooks, anatomical and genomic data, and extensive pages in the Tree of Life and Encyclopedia of Life web projects, will provide resources to researchers and educators. Outreach will include videos and broadcasts about marine exploration and applications of fundamental biological research across the biomedical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Evolutionary Role of Predation: 

Several of the questions addressed in this project sought to identify controls on the evolutionary history of the Crinoidea, the oldest extant class of Echinodermata. In several studies we specifically asked whether predation pressure has affected the evolutionary history of this group. This required documenting predation and finding a means of quantifying its magnitude, a non­trivial task in living and past communities. We developed a method for assessing predation pressure from the observed frequency of injuries and the rates of healing (regeneration). Observations made from a manned submersible over a span of 5 years (Roatan, Honduras), by scuba, and from specimens housed in museum collections, documented frequencies of injuries and predation pressure as a function of depth. Results indicate that predation pressure on crinoids decreases with depth, consistent with the hypothesis that the deep sea represents a refuge from predation. This result is in agreement with increases in predation being a factor that drove many crinoid groups into greater depths, a pattern well-documented in the fossil record.

We also asked whether the fossil record holds other information relevant to evolutionary importance of biotic interactions. We found trends among Paleozoic and post-Paleozoic crinoids as interpretable in terms of their interactions with fishes, as well as benthic invertebrates. We were able to demonstrate that selection pressure on crinoids was not caused by direct predation, but as “collateral damage” from predation on the organisms that infest them (mollusks, arthropods, and annelids).

 

Diversity history of comatulids:

A number of projects centered on the diversity history of comatulid crinoids (feather stars). Today, comatulids are the dominant crinoids—they are the most diverse (>500 spp), most abundant (10’s of individuals m-2), and have the greatest bathymetric range (tops of coral reefs to abyssal depths) and latitudinal distribution (found in all oceans, from equator to high latitudes). Although the fossil record of comatulids extends back ~200 my, it provides no hint of their current success—at no time are their fossils diverse or abundant. This raises the question: is their success a very recent phenomenon, or did it start well in the geologic past but remains hidden by vagaries of the record? There are many potential reasons why comatulid diversity history may be obscured—they are most common today in environments with low preservation potential, each individual is made up of 1000’s very small skeletal elements bound together by soft tissues that tend to disintegrate quickly after death. We quantified the quality of the comatulid fossil record by employing a capture-mark-recapture (CMR) method. The CMR allows for simultaneous estimation of both duration and detection rate, and allows for complex models that vary these by time, space, taxon, and more. Our results suggest that the comatulid fossil record of is highly heterogeneous, with over an order of magnitude variability in detection rate.

To overcome problems with the comatulid fossil record, we chose to examine how the morphological diversity (referred to as disparity) of the most common comatulid skeletal element, the centrodorsal, changed over time. This approach is less sensitive to sampling problems than are methods that rely on taxon counts, or those that require complete specimens. We found that after their Triassic origin, comatulid disparity increased rapidly into the Jurassic, but did not change significantly in the three subsequent time intervals. In fact, a small, non-significant decrease was detected in each successive time interval through to the Recent.  Thus the high diversity of extant comatulids (+500 species) relative to their low diversity in the fossil record is likely a preservational/sampling artifact. Together with recent molecular studies of crinoid phylogeny, there are good reasons to suspect that comatulid success has very deep evolutionary roots.

 

Material Science: 

One intriguing result of our investigations relates to the properties of biomaterials, in this instance, the connective tissues (ligament) of echinoderms. It is generally accepted that muscle is the only biological tissue capable of active contraction, and its structure and properties have been thoroughly explored. Unlike muscle, ligament is not known to be actively contractile, but rather to possess stable and unchanging physical properties (stiffness, strength, etc.). However, it has been known for decades that echinoderm ligament is unusual: it can undergo rapid changes in viscoelastic properties (stiffness; strength) that are actively controlled by the animal and play an important role in echinoderm biology. For example, echinoderms can actively shed body parts (autotomy) by changing the stiffness/strength of ligament. It has also been suggested that the echinoderm ligament may be contractile, even though it lacks muscular tissue. These suggestions find some support in several experimental studies. Our in situ submersible observations of the sea lily, Democrinus, confirm contractility of its ligament. Although the mechanism responsible for contractility remains unknown, this property seems unique to the Echinodermata, has important implications for their biology and evolutionary history, and deserves further study.
